review.title: Increasing Papers' Discoverability with Precise Semantic Labeling: the sci.AI Platform
review.abstract: The number of published findings in biomedicine increases continually. At the same time, specifics of the domain's terminology complicates the task of relevant publications retrieval. In the current research, we investigate influence of terms' variability and ambiguity on a paper's likelihood of being retrieved. We obtained statistics that demonstrate significance of the issue and its challenges, followed by presenting the sci.AI platform, which allows precise terms labeling as a resolution.

sections.heading: 1. Key objectives of the study and its significance
sections.text: Over the past two decades, bioscience articles have become much more complex, reflecting technological evolution, particularly the experiments of OMICs, increasing collaboration between multiple institutions, and the inclusion of more advanced mathematics and statistics applied to data. In many publications, plain unstructured text is supported by algorithms, code, and multiple files of processed and raw data sets with annotated metadata and graphics. Recently, the entire field of "meta-analysis" has evolved to describe "dry laboratory studies" to normalize, unify, and analyze many similar data sets derived from different labs and projects.

sections.heading: 2. State of the art in the field of biomedical texts semanticization
sections.text: However, there is no solid solution for biomedical markup that combines all the latest advances in each area in a single package. A current limitation is the lack of a single scheme for the life sciences. Previous related initiatives include W3C Schollar HTML [11] and JATS4R [12], but both schemes do not provide a common denominator for the life sciences.
